annotation.TEXT: The Giant Metool (who has literally no frames of animation) is one of the only bosses in the game that presents any kind of challenge. His only method of attacking is to jump around and summon smaller metools (which can easily pile up if you don't deal with them). While you'd think it would be possible to just cheese this fight with the Ape Quake, the Giant's hit-box is actually positioned off the ground. To make things even more confusing, it's also set in such a way that you can't hit him while he's facing away from you.

Going on from there, the enemy types and their basic functions definitely need to be expanded upon. Nearly everything in this game is too simple for its own good, which can easily be improved with better coding. Again, a better engine heavily plays in to this, but I don't think it's impossible to make some decent AI with the current one (but it would still be preferable to switch).

Even most of the bosses in this fortress are barely worth commenting on (as you'll soon be able to tell by this first one). Compared to most of the 8 main bots, these guys somehow go down even quicker to their weakness affiliations.

The fortress stages are pretty much in the same boat as the regular levels, only they're slightly longer and with more winding paths. There are a few, occasional gimmicks (such as conveyor belts that lack any form of animation) and roughly 2 or so new enemy types later on. Beyond that however, there's not a whole lot to talk about here.

With all that being said however, there are a few things this game does manage to do right. The chiptune selection is (for a decent portion of the stages) pretty good. Even though it's not following the whole "pure 8-bit format" (but then again, what does in this game?), it's still an interesting change of pace. The auto-save feature is also very nice, and is far more welcome than any password system.

Just to note: No, the YouTube player doesn't stop here. What you're seeing here actually happened in-game during this recording - the game actually froze up during Not-Dr. Wily's intro (and it did so every single time I tried to record it). The game footage does come back, even though it skips the initial look at his rather silly fortress (you'll be able to catch a glimpse of it as it transitions to the stage, and see it fully once the first fortress level is complete).

My main suggestion at this point would be to overhaul the engine or switch to something far more stable. Even though I'm not a fan of most of his works, I'd say Blyka's engine might be a good starting point for an overhaul. N64-Mario's engine is also a potential option as well, though it'll probably come down to a matter of personal preference as to which one is more accurate. In either case, those engines would probably be better suited for this game.

Yes, that is the actual fortress (and yes, the game actually brings you back to the stage select and auto-saves every time you beat a level, meaning all of your weapons get refilled in the process. In the very least, the game gets a few points in its favor for not making the end-game a complete hassle in those regards).

Fortunately, the creator themselves seems to have taken notice of this. I may as well take the time to make some suggestions, given they actually want to improve this (unlike some other fan-game creators out there). First and foremost, the engine for this game is easily the biggest problem. Everything moves way too fast, from the player, to the enemies, and even the projectiles. The hit-boxes and parry-system are vague at best, and everything in general feels extremely loose and very floaty.

If the creator is going to make some improvements to this game, my final suggestion would be to stick with the chiptune music (though perhaps change a few tracks), and keep the auto-save feature. Beyond that, I don't have much else to talk about or suggest. In the very least, I hope some of these will be taken into consideration.

Second phase involves the disappearing/reappearing saucer gimmick, only here, it's pretty much instantaneous as to where he shows up (along with the speed of the missiles he fires). The Desert Storm is pretty much your best friend in this phase for obvious reasons. It might not be his weakness, but it at least makes things more manageable.

So then, that's basically Rockbot in a nutshell. Honestly, I'm not sure if there's any more I can say on this. I think it's one of those games that you can just look at and point out what's wrong with it. Perhaps it's not quite as bad as Mega Man Origins or Project Zero in most regards, but it still needs quite a bit of work.

Finally, the weapons are in need of some serious help (even the decent ones). Ape Quake and Dynamite Flash are fine for the most part (with the potential exception of refining the screen-rumbling animation on the former and scrapping the delayed start-up on the latter). Everything else however is in need of a serious overhaul or improvement as to how the weapon functions.

The first phase against Not-Dr. Wily is downright annoying. The Frog Coil is actually required in order to avoid him at all. Honestly though, if you've stocked up on tanks, there's no reason to do that (just abuse them if you have any left from the Boss Rush).

Here we have the only other instance of a Sniper Joe type enemy (aside from the Magic Joe in Mage Bot's stage). Honestly, these enemies would actually be kind of threatening if not for the fact that their attacks are always angled downwards (coupled with most of their positioning here, and they're all relatively harmless).

I was actually going to put down my suggestions for how to improve each of these in the annotations, but I would have run out of room and time as a result. As such, I'm putting them in the description. In either case, that's about all I can think of for now.

Oh, he can shoot at you as well (either that, or he's stuck on his own Metools). While we're on the subject of coding errors, I'd also like to point out that my health and ammo bars were partly concealed by the boss door as well.

One of the only other enemy types in this game, which apparently tries to be like the moles from MM2. Even with their only appearance here, they're not immune from more coding errors (notice how the other ones flash when one takes a hit).
